III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to

Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was sexually abused by staff.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant received a copy of the court summons authored
by Attorney and sent the summons to Secondary Consultant
on 1/2/24. Complainant does not have any further details about
the allegations. Complainant is not associated with this facility.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility by
Secondary Consultant on 1/3/24. Supervisor was working at the
facility when Youth A was placed there and when Staff 1 was
working at the facility. Supervisor does not recall any complaints
or concerns regarding the allegations ever being disclosed
previously.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at Bellamy Creek
Correctional Facility alone by MDHHS Worker on 1/19/24, and
face to face by this Consultant in conjunction with MDHHS
Worker on 2/20/24. Youth A reported he resided at the facility in
2009. While at the facility, Staff 1 was assigned as Youth A’s
advocate counselor and would advocate for Youth A in meetings
to determine if Youth A would be able to move up levels in the
program. Youth A was able to provide a physical description of
Staff 1 and Staff 1’s first name but could not provide Staff 1’s last
name. Youth A reported around summer 2010, Staff 1 took him to
an ice cream shop called Jersey Junction in East Town to get ice
cream. Youth A reported while Staff 1 was driving, Staff 1 pulled
2

out his penis and told Youth A to “suck it”. Youth A reported he
told Staff 1 no and then Staff 1 pulled into the Family Dollar
parking lot located on Wealthy Street. Youth A reported Staff 1
told him he could drop Youth A’s levels in the program and Youth
A would be stuck at the facility. Youth A reported he stated he
didn’t care and refused to do it. Youth A reported Staff 1 drove to
the ice cream shop, purchased ice cream for them, and they
returned to the facility. Afterwards, Youth A reported he was
prevented from going up a level and Staff 1 reported it was
because Youth A talked down to him. Shortly after, Youth A
reported he received a new advocate. Youth A reported he did not
disclose this incident or information to any staff and denied telling
his therapist about it because he was too embarrassed. Youth A
reported he felt if he told his therapist, he would need to work on
the issue in counseling before being allowed to leave the facility.
Youth A reported he also recalled on another occasion, Staff 1
grabbed or smacked Youth A’s butt while walking up the stairs at
the facility. Youth A reported he smacked Staff 1’s hand away and
cursed at him. Youth A denied Staff 1 saying anything to him.
Youth A denied reporting the incident to anyone.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 2/13/24 in conjunction
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported he started working at the
facility in fall of 2007 and left in 2012. Staff 1 reported he was an
advocate for a handful of youth while at the facility and it was his
job to document progress about behavioral issues the youth were
having on the unit, educational progress, and compliance with
rules/policies. Staff 1 reported there was a staff meeting once per
week where they held an all staff vote on a merit-based system to
determine which youth would change levels. Staff 1 reported he
then switched roles to an activity’s therapist for the last 2 years of
his employment. Staff 1 could remember Youth A’s first name, but
not his last name and couldn’t recall any other information about
him. MDHHS Worker showed Staff 1 a picture of Youth A and
Staff 1 reported he thought he might have been Youth A’s
advocate for a short window. Staff 1 reported he doesn’t
remember taking Youth A on any outings or doing any activities
with Youth A. Staff 1 reported he never took any youth, including
Youth A, on an outing for ice cream or to Family Dollar. Staff 1
reported he never asked Youth A for any sexual favors and never
threatened to drop him levels if he didn’t comply. Staff 1 reported
he never touched or smacked Youth A on the butt, even in a
playful way. Staff 1 reported he understood the boundaries he had
to have as a part of his role at the facility, and never crossed those
boundaries or interacted with any youth, including Youth A, in an
inappropriate way.
3

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Court Summons authored by Attorney dated 12/26/23
outlines a civil lawsuit against the facility by Youth A. It
notes:
o “On or about the summer of 2010, [Staff 1] sexually
assaulted [Youth A]”.
o “On at least three (3) occasions, [Staff 1] committed
similar sexual assaults against [Youth A]”.
o “[Staff 1] assaulted and battered [Youth A] by, inter
alia, nonconsensual sex and unwanted touching”.
• USP Contacts for Youth A note Staff 1 was Youth A’s
Youth Counselor Advocate from approximately 1/15/10-
9/3/10. Staff 1 completed an advocate visit with Youth A on
1/23/10 and completed approximately weekly goal reviews.
Staff 1 then became an assistant activity’s therapist and
worked with Youth A and Staff 2 in that capacity
approximately once per week from approximately 9/8/10-
3/9/11.
• USP for Youth A dated 6/12/10-9/10/10 authored by
Therapist. The report notes Youth A was moved to Level 4
in the program on 3/31/10. In July 2010, staff noted that
Youth A continued to struggle with demonstrating empathy
toward peers, being disrespectful to peers, and dealing with
frustration appropriately. He had been working as Unit
Chore Monitor but was removed from that position due to
his frequently acting superior and/or disrespectful to others.
From mid-July to mid-August 2010, Youth A began arguing
with staff about consequences. His adult interaction goal
dropped to 71%. While this was still acceptable, it was a
significant drop from 91% in June and 81% in July. During
the same time, his leadership goal dropped from 97% to
73%. Additionally, his participation in Group
Initiatives/Activity therapy deteriorated significantly. The
report for August indicated that Youth A continued to act
superior to others, was disrespectful to peers less
physically capable, sometimes would disengage from the
group, and struggled with responding to staff prompts. Due
to all these issues, Youth A was moved back to Level 3 on
8/18/10.
• Notes from Staff Meeting dated 8/18/10 (unknown author)
states “[Youth A]’s behavior on the unit during this report
period seems to have taken a turn for the negative, as
4

reflected by his goals. He has been consistently
disrespectful towards both peers and staff members and
struggles to accept direction from nearly any source.
Because of this, and in consideration of his abilities, this
writer recommends dropping [Youth A] from level four to
level three.”
• Youth A’s “Off-Grounds Flight Plan” approval slips were
reviewed. These note the date, time, destination, location,
and supervisor of Youth A’s off-grounds activities. Youth A
participated in 17 off-grounds activities between 2/17/10-
12/13/10. None of those activities were to get ice cream
and none of the activities were supervised by Staff 1.
• Staff 1 stopped working at the facility in 2012. His
employee file was purged in 2019 due to the facility’s
retention policy of keeping employee files for 7 years.
Limited files were able to be restored by the facility’s IT
department, but discipline and training records were unable
to be restored. According to Staff 1’s annual performance
evaluations from 2009-2012, there were no concerns
surrounding Staff 1 having inappropriate relationships or
boundaries with any youth.
• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment Program
Suspected Staff Misconduct Policy (created 4/2/03; revised
2/25/20) states it is expected staff always respect the
emotional, physical, and mental boundaries of the
residents. It outlines the process for reporting and
investigating staff misconduct, including safety planning
and additional reporting guidelines, if necessary.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. There is no evidence to support Youth
A’s claims he was sexually abused by Staff 1. Staff 1 denies he
took Youth A, or any other youth, on an outing for ice cream,
denies asking Youth A for any sexual favors, and denies
threatening to drop Youth A levels in the program if he didn’t
comply with sexual favors. Documentation in Youth A’s file notes
Youth A struggled in the program and was dropped a level in the
program for multiple reasons, which was a decision made during a
staff meeting on 8/18/10. In addition, documentation in Youth A’s
file does not show any evidence Youth A was taken on any off-
grounds outings by Staff 1.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
